intro: Mentha linnaei var. germanica, commonly known as German mint, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, serrated leaves that emit a strong mint scent when crushed. Its flowers are small, tubular, and usually pink or purple, appearing in whorls along the stem. German mint is often cultivated for its medicinal properties and as a decorative plant in gardens.
